events.summary: Arnold Schoenberg made his grand entrance into Vienna, Austria, completing the puzzle of a lower middle-class Jewish family. It was just a regular day, but who knew this infant would later turn music upside down?

In his twenties, Schoenberg dabbled in orchestrating operettas, making some coins while crafting his own musical masterpieces like 'Verklärte Nacht.' It's like he was balancing his day job while plotting to revolutionize music.

Schoenberg tied the knot with Mathilde Zemlinsky, making him part of a family tree that saw him circulate among musicians and composers. Little did he know; marital bliss would soon become a temporary relocation to Drama City.

While wrestling with personal heartache, Schoenberg decided it was time to throw out keys entirely and composed 'You lean against a silver-willow.' In a bold move, he bid farewell to key signatures forever! A brave new world of sound!

In 1912, Schoenberg unleashed 'Pierrot lunaire', a cycle that blended poetry with music, creating a genre explosion nobody saw coming. It was so avant-garde that it left some listeners wondering if they had accidentally entered an art gallery instead of a concert hall.

Drafted into military service in his forties, Schoenberg humorously compared his own musical battles with the war, while secretly mulling over unfinished works. Clearly, the universe had other plans for his productivity!

Schoenberg, in response to a lack of modern music appreciation, founded the Society for Private Musical Performances to showcase contemporary composers. It’s like he created an exclusive club where only the coolest kids were allowed in!

Schoenberg didn't just break the rules; he reinvented them with his twelve-tone method. This new system of organizing pitches was so revolutionary it's like he established a new order in the music galaxy, where only he understood the map!

As the Nazis began their ascent, Schoenberg hopped on a boat to America. He came seeking a new life, musical freedom, and a lack of folks following him around with pitchforks. Imagine arriving in a new land like a musical superhero!

After becoming a US citizen in 1941, Schoenberg decided to let off some steam by mocking fascism in 'Ode to Napoleon.' One could say he relished being both a composer and a satirist, using melodies to take a jab at tyranny. Talk about double-duty!

In 1947, Schoenberg poured his grief and reflections on the Holocaust into 'A Survivor from Warsaw', a piece that was both a tribute and a testament to resilience. It showed that even in heavy themes, there's a space for the power of sound.

Schoenberg, after a remarkable and often quirky career, took his final bow in Los Angeles. The music world paused to reflect on the master of modernism who danced with dissonance and explored the outer realms of tonality. What a send-off!

After a vacation in France, Schoenberg got the memo that Germany was no longer a safe spot for him, leading to his big move across the pond. Membership in the Jewish religion was reclaimed, and he embraced American life with a flair that even made him change the spelling of his name for local convenience. Comic relief: he probably thought adding a 'c' would make him sound more American, like he was fitting in with a crowd that just loved 'cheese on their nachos'.

Once in the US, Schoenberg needed to find a way to pay the rent. So, he began teaching at various music schools including the fancy University of California, Los Angeles. His salary was friendly enough to afford a house near Shirley Temple, which surely led to some interesting neighborhood gatherings – coffee and pastries around the piano while the Temple kids threw in some tap dancing for good measure!

Finally feeling at home, Schoenberg decided to seal the deal and became a US citizen. He probably celebrated with a barbecue, or at least some cookies, feeling a swell of patriotism as he waved his new flag – or, more likely, a music sheet!

In what might be his most profound work, Schoenberg channeled his emotions into 'A Survivor from Warsaw.' It's almost like he could hear the cries of history echoing, all while crafting a piece that doubled as a reminder of both pain and resilience. A bit like ordering a deeply emotional Berliner donut – it's sweet, but you can't ignore the bittersweet stuff inside.

In a twist of fate befitting his notorious superstition about dying on multiples of 13, Schoenberg passed away on his 76th birthday, which magically added up to 13. Ironically, it seems astrology might have been the only thing that made him nervous enough to spend his birthday in bed. Poor guy didn't even get cake!
After some early hiccups, Schoenberg finally got a thumbs up from the audience with his tone poem Pelleas und Melisande in Berlin. Talk about a glow-up, right?

During the Vienna première of Gurre-Lieder, Schoenberg must have thought he was at a rock concert with a 15-minute ovation and a fancy laurel crown to top it off. Who knew classical music could get that wild?

The Chamber Symphony No. 1 felt like a wallflower at its première, but when it hit the stage again at the Skandalkonzert, it became the talk of the town—complete with audience drama involving door keys and fistfights. Now that's how you make an entrance!

Schoenberg took a little jab at Igor Stravinsky's neoclassical trend in his poem 'Vielseitigkeit'. Apparently, Stravinsky was 'Der kleine Modernsky' to Schoenberg's discerning eye, a true mark of witty rivalry!

Schoenberg wasn't too thrilled when a character in Mann’s Doctor Faustus mirrored his twelve-tone technique. He wrote letters to Mann, likely filled with musical grumbles about letting literary figures steal his thunder!

Schoenberg's twelve-tone system became the hottest topic among musicians, acting like a spark that ignited the creativity of many American composers. You could say his ideas spread like musical wildfire!

Just when people thought he'd fade into the backdrop, Schoenberg's first composition found its way into the world. The critics had their fun trying to decipher what this new kid on the block was up to.

The world was treated to a blend of voice and instruments when Schoenberg premiered 'Pierrot Lunaire'. Audiences were either mesmerized or confused, but one thing was clear: it was a theatrical spectacle!

Schoenberg decided that the world of music could use a bit more chaos and less predictability with the invention of his twelve-tone technique. Music theorists everywhere grabbed their pencils and papers to catch up!

events.event: Founding of the Society for Private Musical Performance
events.summary: Schoenberg established this exclusive musical society, proving once again that he loved music more than the average listener. Invitations were limited, but the impact of the performances? Far-reaching!
Schoenberg's unique style influenced film scoring, leading to a fusion of his innovative sounds with the glitz and glamour of Hollywood. Even cinema couldn’t resist his musical charm!

In a fit of artistic inspiration, Schoenberg composed 'Verklärte Nacht', a piece so compelling that it made everyone wonder what else they were missing in music. It was as if he was saying, 'Hey, listen up, I mean business!'
Schoenberg decided that traditional harmony was so last century. He kicked it to the curb and made a bold leap into atonality, proving that rules are meant to be broken, especially in music!
With 'Erwartung', Schoenberg brought drama and emotion to the operatic stage. Apparently, he wasn't satisfied with just music alone; he needed to add a little melodrama to keep things spicy!
Schoenberg invented the twelve-tone technique, creating a musical recipe that was as revolutionary as any grand culinary invention. He basically turned musical notes into the ultimate gourmet dish!

In Los Angeles, Schoenberg kept composing and influencing the future of music. It's like he found the fountain of youth for composers—while the world was busy with swing and jazz, he was revolutionizing music behind the scenes!

compositions.title: Das Buch der hängenden Gärten, Op.15
Phantasy for Violin and Piano, Op.47
